com.github.thorbenkuck.netcom2.network.shared.clients

Interface Connection

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Loggable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractConnection, TCPDefaultConnection, UDPDefaultConnection

    public interface Connection
extends Loggable
    A Connection is an object-representation of an physical connection between the ClientStart and the ServerStart.

    Such a Connection is build in an similar way as the java.nio-package. The idea is, that you have a ReceivingService, that handles incoming objects asynchronously and an SendingService that handles outgoing objects asynchronously.

    Both are Runnable classes and will use NetCom2Utils for extracting procedures into other Threads.

    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    1.0
    See Also:
    ConnectionFactory

      • Methods inherited from interface com.github.thorbenkuck.netcom2.interfaces.Loggable

        setLogging

    • Method Detail

      • close

        void close()
    throws IOException
        Closes the Connection.

        This will close the underlying connection-type. In the case of the AbstractConnection, this is the Socket.

        It may throw an IOException, if anything goes wrong while closing the Connection.

        Throws:
        IOException

      • setup

        void setup()
        Sets up internal dependencies.

        Depending on the implementation, this requires an already established connection to the source.

        In the case of the AbstractConnection, this means it creates the SendingService and ReceivingService, that listen on the Connection and handles send/received Objects.

      • removeOnDisconnectedConsumer

        void removeOnDisconnectedConsumer(java.util.function.Consumer<Connection> consumer)
        Removes an set Consumer, that is called once the Connection disconnects.
        Parameters:
        consumer - the Consumer, that should be removed.
        See Also:
        Client.addDisconnectedHandler(DisconnectedHandler), addOnDisconnectedConsumer(Consumer)

      • write

        void write(Object object)
        Writes an Object to this Connection.

        This means the Object is send "to the other side of the Connection". In fact, an Connection is only the entry/exit point. So writing an Connection means, it will be received by another instance of the same type, which represents the corresponding exit point.

        This method is used by the Client.

        Parameters:
        object - the Object that should be send over the Connection.
        See Also:
        Client.send(Object), Client.send(Class, Object), Client.send(Connection, Object)

      • addObjectSendListener

        void addObjectSendListener(Callback<Object> callback)
        Adds a listener, that will be called once an Object, added with write(Object), was successfully send.
        Parameters:
        callback - the Callback, that should be called, once the Object is called.

      • addObjectReceivedListener

        void addObjectReceivedListener(Callback<Object> callback)
        Adds an listener, that will be called once a Object, was received.

        These Callback will be triggered after the CommunicationRegistration is finished to handel the received Object.

        Parameters:
        callback - the Callback, that should be called, once a Object is received.

      • setThreadPool

        @Experimental
void setThreadPool(ExecutorService executorService)
        This method sets the ExecutorService, that the ReceivingService and the SendingService are executed in.

        NOTE: Currently this does NOT work!

        Parameters:
        executorService - the ExecutorService, that should be used.

      • startListening

        Awaiting startListening()
        This method returns an internally Awaiting instance, that unlocks once this Connection is successfully listens.
        Returns:
        the internal synchronization mechanism.

      • addOnDisconnectedConsumer

        com.github.thorbenkuck.keller.pipe.PipelineCondition<Connection> addOnDisconnectedConsumer(java.util.function.Consumer<Connection> consumer)
        Adds an Consumer, that should be trigger, once this Connection disconnects.

        All of those consumers are executed within an Pipeline.

        Parameters:
        consumer - the Consumer, that should consume this Connection, once this Connection is disconnected.
        Returns:
        an PipelineCondition, that you may use to state whether or not the Consumer should be executed.

        Returns the OutputStream for this Connection.

        Throws:
        IOException - if something goes wrong.

      • getSendInterface

        BlockingQueue<Object> getSendInterface()
        Returns the Object sending queue.

        Objects are added to this BlockingQueue. If you want to just dump any Object into this Connection, you may use this. The SendingService will take this Object (sooner or later) and send it.

        Note, that no Callback will be added.

        Returns:
        an internally maintained send interface in the type of an BlockingQueue.

      • getSession

        Session getSession()
        Returns the Session, this Connection is identified with.
        Returns:
        the Session for this Connection.
